Award.AwardTitle: Preparing Mathematical Sciences Students for Business, Industry, and Government Careers (Pre-BIG)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PreBIG program will provide mathematical sciences faculty with tools and training to help them better prepare students for business, industry, and government (BIG) careers and will provide mathematical sciences students with an opportunity to conduct research on problems related to BIG. To accomplish this, the PIs will produce a set of training videos, conduct summer training workshops for faculty, organize a semester-long course and competition for undergraduate students, organize a summer recognition conference for participating undergraduate students, and secure support from BIG entities. The program includes a strong undergraduate research component since student participation in research has been shown to be effective in improving student success in graduating with a STEM (science, technology, engineering, or mathematics) degree. The undergraduate students will be mentored so that they develop skills that will help them to succeed in a career in STEM, including knowledge of career opportunities, experience in working on problems from BIG organizations, and experience in developing effective writing and oral presentation skills. The MAA's focus on supporting underrepresented groups in the mathematical sciences will be reflected in this program as well.

In business, industry, and government, there is a tremendous demand for STEM graduates. Yet, in the mathematical sciences, many students and faculty are unaware of the numerous career opportunities in these sectors, and faculty may not know how to adequately prepare students for STEM careers outside academia. To help remedy this situation, we propose a program to better prepare students in the mathematical sciences to succeed in careers in business, industry, and government (BIG). This program will:
a) Increase awareness among mathematical sciences faculty and undergraduate majors of non-academic career options and related internship opportunities.
b) Facilitate connections among mathematical sciences faculty and people working in BIG in the same geographic region.
c) Offer undergraduate students research opportunities focused on real-world BIG problems.
d) Provide training for undergraduate students and faculty in successful approaches to BIG problems along with requisite technical and communications skills.
e) Require less and less external funding as time goes on.

This project is jointly supported by the Division of Mathematical Sciences and the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities within NSF's Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In business, industry, and government (BIG), there is a tremendous demand for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) graduates. Yet, in the mathematical sciences, many students and faculty are unaware of these opportunities and faculty may not know how to prepare students for STEM careers. For the past four years we have been directing PIC Math (Preparation for Industrial Careers in Mathematical Sciences), a program that connects mathematics and statistics students and faculty with people in BIG, and helps undergraduate students better prepare for non-academic careers. PIC Math is a program of the Mathematical Association of America (MAA), funded by an NSF grant and supported by the Society of Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM).

The PIC Math program works with mathematics faculty members throughout the United States to help them prepare mathematical sciences students for BIG careers by engaging their students in research problems that come directly from BIG partner organizations. The PIC Math program consists of four primary activities: (a) a 3-day faculty training workshop to prepare faculty for the PIC Math program, including the identification and communication with potential BIG partners, (b) a semester-long course run at each local institution, in which students work on research problems that come directly from the chosen BIG partner, (c) a student research experience culminating in solution submission and evaluation, and (d) a student summer recognition conference with student talks and poster presentations in conjunction with a national meeting of a professional society.

During the first three years of PIC Math we had over 100 BIG partners who have provided research problems and consultants for the students including such companies as Colorado Department of Transportation, Sandia National Laboratory, the Kansas City government, the Field Museum of Chicago, Greensboro North Carolina Police Department, US Water Utility Group, and Massachusetts General Hospital. We have had 107 faculty participants representing 101 different colleges and universities from 33 U.S. states, including 10 Hispanic Serving Institutions and 6 Historically Black Colleges or Universities. We have had over 1400 undergraduate student participants of whom 40% are women and 21% are from minority groups underrepresented in the mathematical sciences. As a direct result of the PIC Math program, 147 research papers and over 150 conference presentations have been co-authored by the teams of undergraduate students.

To address the broader goal of preparing mathematics faculty members to collaborate on BIG problems, the PIC Math project hosted in its final summer a training workshop on essential methods of data science, which is of central relevance to the majority of PIC Math projects.  To address the broader goal of increasing national awareness of BIG careers for mathematical sciences students, the project produced 8 industrial mathematics case study videos highlighting research problems encountered by mathematical scientists working in BIG as well as a successful communications campaign to bring stakeholders to these videos and related PIC Math materials. This campaign reached almost 2 million Facebook users (resulting in 170,000 views of the videos) and over 200,000 YouTube users (resulting in over 60,000 views of the videos), results we believe accomplish the project goals and provide a blueprint for communication and dissemination plans for the future.
